description: APPLICATION FOR 1. ERECTION OF A SINGLE STOREY REAR EXTENSION, HIP TO GABLE AND REAR DORMER ROOF EXTENSION, AND INSTALLATION OF TWO ROOFLIGHTS ON THE FRONT ROOFSLOPE. 2. DEMOLITION OF GARAGE AND ERECTION OF A TWO STOREY DWELLINGHOUSE WITH ANCILLARY PARKING IN FRONT
decision_conditions: Condition : 1 - By reason of the lack of details of the proposed appearance of the front and rear garden and boundary treatment, the scheme is considered to increase visual permeability into a predominantly hard surfaced forecourt to the detriment of the overall appearance of the locality.  The proposal would not comply with, in particular, National Planning Policy Framework 2023 chapter 4, 12, and 15, London Plan 2021 Policy D3, G6 and G7, Merton Core Planning Strategy 2011 Policies CS13 and CS14, and Merton Sites and Policies Plan (2014) Policies DMD2 and DMD3.

Condition : 2 - In the absence of a legal agreement securing a car free agreement the proposal would adversely impact on the free flow of traffic in the locality to the detriment of highway and pedestrian safety.  The scheme would be contrary to, in particular, National Planning Policy Framework 2023 chapter 9, London Plan 2021 Policies T6 and T6.1, Merton Core Planning Strategy (2011) Policies CS20 (Parking, Servicing and Delivery), and Policies DMT1, DMT2 and DM T3 (Car Parking and Servicing Standards) of the Adopted Merton Sites and Policies Plan (2014).

Condition : 3 - In absence of a layout plan showing details of the location of the proposed parking bay, the front boundary and dropped kerb, the scheme fails to provide a satisfactory form of vehicular access to the detriment of the free flow of traffic to the detriment of highway and pedestrian safety in the locality and is considered to adversely impact on the visual amenity of the locality. The proposal would not comply with, in particular, National Planning Policy Framework 2023 Chapter 9, London Plan 2021 Policies T6 and T6.1, Merton Core Planning Strategy (2011) policy CS14 and CS20, and Merton Sites and Policies Plan (2014) Policies DM D2 and DMT2.

Condition : 4 - By reason of unsatisfactory layout and absence of secure, integrated, convenient and accessible cycle parking facilities the scheme is considered to adversely impact on the free flow of traffic in the locality to the detriment of highway and pedestrian safety and fails to provide a sustainable form of development.  The proposal is contrary to, in particular, National Planning Policy Framework 2023 Policy 9, London Plan 2021 Policy T5, Merton's Core Strategy (2011) Policy CS 20, Merton's Sites and Policies Plan (2014) policy DM T2.

Condition : 5 - By reason of loss of front garden vegetation and absence of satisfactory replacement planting, the proposal would adversely impact on the visual amenity of the locality, biodiversity and ecological value of the locality and thus would not comply with, in particular, National Planning Policy Framework 2023 Chapter 15, London Plan 2021 Policy G6, Merton Core Planning Strategy (2011) policy CS13, Merton Sites and Policies Plan 2014 Policies DM D2 and DMO2.

Condition : 6 - In the absence of an arboricultural survey, arboricultural impact assessment and arboricultural method statement and tree protection plan, the scheme is considered to impact on the health and longevity of the existing off-site tree to the detriment of the visual amenity, biodiversity and ecological value of the locality and would fail to achieve the objectives set out within National Planning Policy Framework 2023 Policy 15, London Plan 2021 Policy G6, Merton Core Planning Strategy (2011) policy CS13, Merton Sites and Policies Plan 2014 Policies DM D2 and DMO2.

Condition : 7 - In accordance with paragraph 38 of the NPPF, The London Borough of Merton (LBM) takes a positive and proactive approach to development proposals focused on solutions. LBM works with applicants/agents in a positive and proactive manner by:

   i) Offering a pre-application advice and duty desk service. 
   ii) Where possible, suggesting solutions to secure a successful outcome.
   iii) As appropriate, updating applicants/agents of any issues that may arise in the processing of their application.

In this instance:

   i) The application was not considered to comply with the provisions of the Development Plan and NPPF as submitted, and would have required substantial changes such that a new application would be required. 
   ii) The application was considered to be fundamentally contrary to the provisions of the Development Plan and the NPPF, and there were not considered to be any solutions to resolve this conflict. 
   iv) It is noted that the applicant/agent did  engage in pre-application discussions.
   v) The applicant is advised to seek pre-application advice on any resubmission.
